conclusion: The processes A→B and C→D are isothermal. In an isothermal process, the temperature T remains constant.
The number of molecules colliding with the wall per unit area per unit time depends on the number density n (number of molecules per unit volume) and the average speed of the molecules.
For an ideal gas, the number density n is inversely proportional to the volume V (i.e., n ∝ 1/V).
In the isothermal process C→D, the volume V changes while the temperature T remains constant.
As we move from state C to state D, the volume V increases (since C→D is an expansion process).

premise: For an ideal gas, the number density n is inversely proportional to the volume V (i.e., n ∝ 1/V). As we move from state C to state D, the volume V increases.
conclusion: Therefore, the number density n decreases because n ∝ 1/V.

premise: Since the number density n decreases from state C to state D, the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time also decreases.
conclusion: The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time decreases from state C to state D.
